questions.text: An 87-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from a nearby skilled nursing facility with confusion and vomiting for the past day. According to the nursing staff, the patient was in her usual state of health before the last 24 hours, during which she was complaining of nausea. She is normally alert and oriented to person, place and time. She has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension, and she was recently discharged from the hospital after having an obstructed kidney stone removed and a postoperative course complicated by recurrent urinary retention. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 121/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over her left flank. A Foley catheter is in place and draining dark brown urine. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient’s current clinical condition?

choices.text: Bacterial ascent up a short urethra

questions.solution:
This elderly female patient presents with signs and symptoms of pyelonephritis, including nausea, vomiting, and costovertebral angle tenderness. Of the risk factors listed, her strongest predisposing risk factor is Foley catheter placement, which likely served as a nidus for her current infection and should be removed promptly for adequate source control. Both cystitis (bladder infection) and pyelonephritis (kidney infection) have multiple risk factors, but the mechanism of transmission is largely related to ascending bacterial infection.  

Bacteria are constantly moving into the urethral tract from the periurethral area, vaginal cavity, and perianal area; further transmission of these bacteria may occur when host defense systems fail, allowing bacteria to grow to substantial numbers before spontaneous clearance. One such example is a failed vesicoureteral reflux mechanism, which then allows retrograde propulsion of urine, enabling bacteria to ascend the ureter.  

Additional risk factors for the development of urinary tract infections are divided into those that expose the host to potential uropathogens and those that enhance colonization by those uropathogens:  

  •  Increased exposure to uropathogens: Foley catheter, frequent sexual intercourse, trauma or surgical manipulation of the urinary tract 
  •  Enhanced colonization of uropathogens: Female gender (due to a shorter urethra), Foley catheter placement,, diabetes, obesity, pregnancy, and obstructive processes (benign prostatic hyperplasia, neurologic conditions) 

Option Analysis

✅ Indwelling urinary catheter  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Impaired urine flow:
Incorrect: Chronic obstructions due to nephrolithiasis or anatomic variability (e.g. posterior urethral valves) may impede flow of urine, allowing bacteria to migrate more easily. This patient has evidence of continued urine output, making this etiology unlikely.   
❌ Bacterial ascent up a short urethra:
Incorrect: Women in general are more likely to sustain urinary tract infections due to shorter urethras; however, in the setting of a Foley placement, the former risk factor becomes inconsequential by comparison.   
❌ Hematogenous bacterial spread  :
Incorrect: Hematogenous bacterial spread is unlikely in this patient without additional evidence of pneumonia, bacteremia, endocarditis, or an additional inciting infectious process.  
❌ Antimicrobial suppression of endogenous flora:
Incorrect: Recent antimicrobial use may precipitate pyelonephritis with more fastidious bacteria, but this patient has not recently taken antimicrobials.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is currently postoperative day 5 after having an open cholecystectomy. She reports worsening suprapubic pain and malaise.  Her vital signs are 37 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 137/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination shows suprapubic tenderness on palpation as well as cloudy urine in her Foley catheter. Which of the following pathogens is most likely causative of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a nosocomial urinary tract infection following Foley catheter placement for her cholecystectomy. Of the pathogens listed, the Enterococcus species has the highest association with catheter-associated urinary tract infections; it is also commonly multidrug resistant.  

Many bacterial species are known to cause both hospital and community acquired urinary tract infections. Overall, Escherichia coli is the most common cause in both of these settings. Other pathogens associated with nosocomial urinary tract infections include enterococcus, serratia marcescens, and pseudomonas aeruginosa. In sexually active women, Staphylococcus Saprophyticus is the second leading cause of urinary tract infections. Proteus mirabilis is commonly associated with chronic urinary tract infections and the formation of struvite stones or staghorn calculi.   

Option Analysis

✅ Enterococcus species:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Klebsiella pneumoniae   :
Incorrect: Klebsiella pneumonia is the third leading cause of urinary tract infections overall. While it is classified as a known cause of nosocomial urinary tract infections, it is overall less common than Enterococcus species.   
❌ Proteus mirabilis:
Incorrect: Proteus mirabilis is associated with chronic pyelonephritis. It is not associated with nosocomial urinary tract infections.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause of urinary tract infections overall, and it is unlikely in this patient presenting with a nosocomial urinary tract infection.   
❌ Staphylococcus saprophyticus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common urinary tract infection in individuals engaging in frequent sexual intercourse. It is unlikely in this patient presenting with a nosocomial urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to a burning sensation with urination. The symptoms started 3 days ago and now cause the patient to wake up multiple times at night to urinate. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is sexually active with their spouse. Physical examination is unremarkable and vital signs are within normal limits. Urinalysis is positive for leukocytes and leukocyte esterase. Urine culture reveals growth of Gram-positive cocci. Which of the following is a feature of the causative organism most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI), likely due to Staphylococcus saprophyticus. Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a Gram-positive coccus (circle-shaped) that grows in clusters, and is a common cause of UTI in women. S. aureus does not generally cause UTI, and S. epidermidis in urine culture, is rare and usually indicates contamination with skin flora.

Like all other staphylococcal species, Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a catalase-positive pathogen, which means that it is able to convert hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. S. saprophyticus is also urease-positive (like S. epidermidis) which helps in the pathogenesis of UTI by converting urea to ammonia. This elevates the pH of the urine and makes it more suitable for bacterial growth. Unlike S. aureus, S. saprophyticus is a coagulase-negative pathogen.

One of the distinguishing features of S. saprophyticus from other staphylococcal species is its resistance to novobiocin. Both S. aureus and S. epidermidis are sensitive to novobiocin. Therefore, novobiocin sensitivity can be used to distinguish between S. saprophyticus and other staphylococcal species.  


Option Analysis

✅ Novobiocin resistant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Coagulase positive:
Incorrect: The most likely cause of this patient’s urinary tract infection is Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is coagulase negative.  
❌ Catalase negative:
Incorrect: All staphylococcal species are catalase positive, including Staphylococcus saprophyticus.  
❌ Intracellular microorganism:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is not an intracellular pathogen.  
❌ Novobiocin sensitive:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is novobiocin resistant while Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are novobiocin sensitive.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with flank pain, malaise, and weight loss over the past several weeks. She states, “I just have no appetite for anything these days.” She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and several episodes of nephrolithiasis. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 94/min and blood pressure is 154/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows a palpable left sided flank mass. She subsequently undergoes a biopsy of the mass with the following histologic finding demonstrated below:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following pathogens is most commonly implicated in this disease process?
questions.solution:
Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XP) is a rare form of chronic pyelonephritis, most commonly implicated with long standing or recurrent urinary tract infections with Proteus mirabilis. Macroscopic tissue demonstrates orange nodules that can mimic renal cell carcinoma tumor nodules. Staghorn calculi are often present as well. This appearance is due to widespread kidney damage and necrosis due to granulomatous tissue containing foamy macrophages in response to the bacteria. This biopsy demonstrates immunohistochemical staining of macrophages and giant cells in a case of XP. The disease occurs in middle-aged women and is most commonly unilateral. Treatment is nephrectomy after a course of antimicrobials to control the local infection.   

Option Analysis

✅ Proteus mirabilis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Staphylococcus epidermidis :
Incorrect: S. epidermidis a common cause of urinary tract infections in patients with indwelling catheters. It is not, however, associated with xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis, which is the likely diagnosis in this patient.  
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa  :
Incorrect: While Pseudomonas aeruginosa is associated with chronic urinary tract infections, it is not the most common bacteria implicated in xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis. It is more commonly found in patients with diabetes.   
❌ Staphylococcus aureus :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause of urinary tract infections overall, and it is not associated with xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis.  
❌ Staphylococcus saprophyticus   :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common urinary tract infection in individuals engaging in frequent sexual intercourse. It is not, however, associated with xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old-woman presents to the clinic with abdominal pain and pain with urination. She reports having frequent sexual intercourse with her male partner. She is otherwise healthy and takes an oral contraceptive pill for birth control. Her vital signs are 37 °C (98.6.°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 15/min and blood pressure is 130/74 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness on palpation. Which of the following virulence factors is most likely causative for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Fimbriae from a Gram-negative indole-positive rod
Adenylate cyclase toxin from a Gram-negative aerobic coccobacillus
Exotoxin A from an aerobic Gram-negative rod
IgA protease from a Gram-negative coccobacillary rod
Adhesin from Gram-positive cocci in clusters

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy female patient is presenting with suprapubic pain, dysuria, and a history of frequent sexual intercourse, which is consistent with a diagnosis of cystitis. Of the virulence factors listed, fimbriae from E. coli is the most likely etiology, since this organism is by far the most common cause of cystitis. Fimbriae allow E. coli to adhere to the urinary epithelium and ascend the urinary tract.  

Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, which typically presents with suprapubic pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency in the absence of systemic symptoms like fever or chills (which would instead suggest  pyelonephritis). Other commonly implicated organisms for cystitis include Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Klebsiella, and Proteus mirabilis.  

Diagnosis of cystitis is made clinically in conjunction with urinalysis findings, which will typically reveal positive leukocyte esterase, positive nitrites, as well as bacteria and >10 WBC/high power field. Urine culture can then be utilized to identify the causative organism. Sterile pyuria (positive leukocyte esterase without nitrites or identified bacteria) is more indicative of urethritis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fimbriae from a Gram-negative indole-positive rod:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Adenylate cyclase toxin from a Gram-negative aerobic coccobacillus:
Incorrect: The adenylate cyclase toxin is unique to Bordetella pertussis, which causes whooping cough. The toxin blunts phagocytosis as well as the production of radical oxygen species by neutrophils and monocytes.  
❌ Exotoxin A from an aerobic Gram-negative rod:
Incorrect: Exotoxin A is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and inhibits elongation factor 2 by ADP-ribosylation of EF2 using NAD+, which ceases the elongation of polypeptides. P. aeruginosa can cause urinary tract infections (UTIs), but it is not the most common organism, and therefore it is unlikely the cause of this otherwise healthy patient’s UTI.  
❌ IgA protease from a Gram-negative coccobacillary rod:
Incorrect: IgA protease is a virulence factor produced by Haemophilus influenzae, enabling the bacteria to adhere to mucous membranes. H. influenzae is not a common cause of urinary tract infections.  
❌ Adhesin from Gram-positive cocci in clusters:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is part of the normal flora of the female genital tract and perineum. It is the second most common cause of urinary tract infections in young women.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a burning sensation that occurs with urination. The symptoms started about two days ago. She has also experienced urinary hesitancy and urgency. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 101/73 mmHg, pulse is 71/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination is notable for mild suprapubic tenderness. She is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and prescribed a three-day course of ciprofloxacin. The patient returns to the clinic after completing the course of antibiotics without symptomatic improvement. A urine culture still reveals the presence of bacteria. What is the mechanism by which bacteria develop resistance to this class of antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Fluoroquinolone antibiotics inhibit prokaryotic topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV. The major mechanism of bacterial resistance against these antibiotics is via chromosome-encoded mutations in DNA topoisomerase and through efflux pumps encoded in both chromosomes and plasmids. The efflux pumps transport drug molecules out of the bacterial cells.  

The fluoroquinolone class of antibiotics includes ciprofloxacin, enoxaparin, norfloxacin, and ofloxacin. Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, and gemifloxacin are known as respiratory fluoroquinolones since they have activity against respiratory pathogens. Fluoroquinolones are used in treating infections by Gram-negative rods in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts, Pseudomonas, and some Gram-positive bacteria.    

This medication class is associated with several adverse effects, including gastrointestinal upset, rashes, headache, and dizziness. They can also cause cartilage damage. As a result, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated for use in pregnant women, nursing mothers, and children under 18 years old. Moreover, fluoroquinolones can cause tendon rupture and tendonitis, particularly in individuals over 60 years old or those concurrently taking prednisone. Finally, fluoroquinolones can cause QT prolongation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Chromosome-encoded mutation in DNA gyrase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Underexpression of bacterial catalase-peroxidase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how Mycobacterium tuberculosis develops resistance to isoniazid (INH). Bacterial catalase-peroxidase is required to convert INH to its active metabolite, inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.
❌ Plasmid-encoded acetyltransferase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how bacteria develop resistance to chloramphenicol. Chloramphenicol is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that blocks peptidyltransferase at the 50S ribosomal subunit. It is not often used due to its side effects, including aplastic anemia and gray baby syndrome. 
❌ Methylation of 23S rRNA-binding site:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism by which bacteria develop resistance to macrolide antibiotics. Methylation at the 23S rRNA-binding site prevents the binding of drug molecules to the ribosome.
❌ Point mutation in ribosomal RNA:
Incorrect: This patient was prescribed a fluoroquinolone. Bacterial resistance to fluoroquinolones occurs through mutations in DNA gyrase, not ribosomal RNA.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the office because of increased urinary frequency and burning with urination for the past 2 days. She has mild lower abdominal discomfort but no abnormal vaginal discharge. The patient has a history of two similar episodes in the past that resolved spontaneously. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in the patient’s father. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.5 F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals mild lower abdominal tenderness. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urine is sent for culture and sensitivity, and the patient is started on empiric treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. This drug inhibits which of the following processes in the bacterial cell?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from acute cystitis and is treated empirically with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, also referred to as TMP-SMX, and is one of the commonly prescribed agents for the treatment of simple urinary tract infection.  

TMP-SMX are antimetabolites that inhibit bacterial replication by blocking the two successive steps in folic acid metabolism: sulfamethoxazole (a sulfonamide) is a structural analog of p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and competes with it for the active site of the enzyme dihydropteroate synthetase (DHPS) in the first step of folate synthesis and prevents the bacteria from making dihydropteroic acid.    

Trimethoprim inhibits the third step of folate synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), preventing the formation of tetrahydrofolic acid (THF).    

Each of these drugs is bacteriostatic when used alone, but a combination of trimethoprim plus sulfamethoxazole is bactericidal for E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Salmonella, and Shigella.  





Option Analysis

❌ Peptidoglycan cross-linking:
Incorrect: Bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan cross-linking is inhibited by penicillin, cephalosporins, carbapenems, and monobactams. TMP-SMX is a sulfonamide combination.  
✅ Bacterial folate metabolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial DNA unwinding:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones prevent DNA gyrase and topoisomerase from unwinding the bacterial double-stranded DNA. Although it can be used for the treatment of uncomplicated cystitis, it is usually preferred when other agents are not available or ineffective.  
❌ mRNA synthesis:
Incorrect: Rifampin inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which is responsible for mRNA synthesis. It is one of the main components of the anti-tuberculosis treatment regime. It is not, however, indicated in the treatment of lower urinary tract infections.  
❌ Peptidoglycan synthesis:
Incorrect: Vancomycin inhibits cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. It is effective against resistant gram-positive infections (e.g., MRSA) and should not be used to empirically treat a lower urinary tract infection.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of increased urinary frequency and burning with urination for the past 2 days. She has mild lower abdominal discomfort but no abnormal vaginal discharge. The patient has a history of 2 similar episodes in the past which was treated adequately with antibiotics. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in the patient’s mother. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.6 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild lower abdominal tenderness. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urine is sent for culture and sensitivity, and the patient is started on empiric treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. The patient returned 4 days later with little improvement in her symptoms. Urine culture sensitivities are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for the treatment failure in this patient?  

 Microorganism  Escherichia coli 
 Drug  Sensitivity (R = resistant, S = susceptible) 
 Penicillin  S 
 Nitrofurantoin  R 
 Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole  R 
 Gentamicin  S 
 Meropenem  S 
 Ciprofloxacin  S

choices.text: Poor interaction with penicillin binding proteins
Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase

questions.solution:
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) combinations act synergistically by blocking folic acid synthesis in two sequential steps and was prescribed to this patient for the treatment of uncomplicated urinary tract infection. As seen in urine culture, E. coli in this patient is resistant to TMP-SMX. Bacterial resistance to sulfonamides is common and may be plasmid-mediated. Sulfamethoxazole (a sulfonamide) is a structural analog of p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and competes with it for the active site of the enzyme dihydropteroate synthetase (DHPS) in the first step of folate synthesis. This competitive inhibition can be overcome by an excess of PABA. Other mechanisms of resistance include decreased intracellular accumulation of the drugs (by decreased uptake), or a decrease in the sensitivity of dihydropteroate synthase to the sulfonamide by alteration in its structure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased synthesis of p-Aminobenzoic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Poor interaction with penicillin binding proteins:
Incorrect: Resistance to penicillins is caused by changes in the PBPs in the bacterial cell membrane, which decreases the penicillin-binding and reduces the ability of the antibiotic to kill the targeted bacteria. This patient is receiving treatment with TMP-SMX.  
❌ Mutated DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Resistance to quinolones is due primarily to chromosomal-encoded mutations that modify the bacterial DNA gyrase. This patient’s bacterial sensitivities show it is sensitive to ciprofloxacin and, moreover, it was not used for treatment in this patient.  
❌ Mutated ribosomal subunit protein:
Incorrect: Resistance to aminoglycosides results from chromosomal mutation (by methylation) in the gene that codes for the target protein in the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome. This patient’s bacterial sensitivities show it is sensitive to gentamicin and, moreover, it was not used for treatment in this patient.  
❌ Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase:
Incorrect: Decreased activity of bacterial catalase-peroxidase is the mechanism of mycobacterial resistance to isoniazid. Mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase activity is required to synthesize the active metabolite of isoniazid that inhibits the growth of M. tuberculosis.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is evaluated for hematuria for the past 2 weeks. She had noticed a red tinge in her urine but denies dysuria or discharge. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis reveals 10 RBC/hpf and no bacteria. CT scan of the abdomen is shown below, along with the results from a biopsy of the lesion.

 

Both images reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

This patient’s lesion most likely developed from which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
Renal oncocytoma is benign neoplasm that arises from the intercalated cells of collecting ducts. It represents approximately 10% of renal neoplasms. On imaging, a characteristic appearance of central stellate scar provides another clue for diagnosis, as seen here. On histology, the tumor is characterized by large eosinophilic cells with abundant mitochondria without perinuclear clearing. Patients are often asymptomatic, and the tumor is found as an incidental mass on imaging. Occasionally, patients may present with painless hematuria, flank pain, and abdominal mass. Resection is often performed to exclude malignancy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Proximal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: Tumors arising from the proximal convoluted tubules are renal cell carcinoma. It is the most common 1° renal malignancy. It is typically seen in men 50–70 years old and is associated with smoking and obesity. On gross morphology, it is often seen as a golden-yellow lesion, due to high lipid content. Histology would demonstrate polygonal clear cells filled with accumulated lipids and carbohydrates.  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Embryonic metanephric blastema:
Incorrect: Tumors that arise from the embryonic metanephric blastema are nephroblastomas (Wilms tumors). This tumor is the most common renal malignancy of early childhood (ages 2–4) and may arise sporadically or as a part of a syndrome (e.g. WAGR syndrome). This patient’s age and histological findings favor another diagnosis.  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Perivascular epithelioid cells:
Incorrect: Tumors that arise from clonal proliferation of perivascular epithelial cells are renal angiomyolipomas. Renal angiomyolipoma may occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis complex. Histology would demonstrate adipose tissue, abnormal blood vessels with thickened walls, and spindle-shaped smooth muscle-like cells.  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Intercalated cells of collecting ducts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
